title: Electronic Reading Device, "Kindle", 2007
provenance: Sent directly to CHNDM by the manufacturer, Amazon.com (Jeff Bezos, founder and CEO), from their headquarters in Seattle, WA., June, 2009.
description: Canted rectangular form of white plastic with large rectangular flat screen set above keyboard occupying slanted lower quarter of face; small rectangular keys set at angle; large rectangular function keys flanking screen; small scroll wheel above right side of keyboard; input jacks and volume control on bottom; grey plastic panel on back.
justification:
Justification text from acquisition file:
Amazon Kindle I and II
The Amazon Kindle is a milestone product, whose design both physical and technological is leading to fundamental change in book publishing, book design, and reading habits.
In development by Amazon since 2004, the Amazon Kindle is a hardware and software platform for reading electronic books. The Kindle I debuted in the fall of 2007, followed by the Kindle II, introduced in February, 2009. Unlike earlier e-reader devices which required connecting to a computer to download book files, the Kindle employs wireless connection.&nbsp; One can simply download books directly from the internet into the Kindle. Currently, 285,000 titles are ready for purchase and instant download from Amazon.com's virtual book store. The Kindle I holds approximately 200 books in its memory; hundreds more on a memory card. 
Another feature of the Kindle is that one can subscribe to magazines and newspapers via the Amazon on-line store, accessing them with the keyboard just below the screen. These virtual publications are sent automatically to the subscriber's Kindle.
The white housing features a large screen and was designed with a quality that Amazon founder and CEO, Jeff Bezos, describes as "bookishness": it has the dimensions of a paperback book, and the width tapers to suggest the bulge toward a book's binding.&nbsp; Both the Kindle I and II weigh about 10 ounces, so are easy to hold. Unlike a computer they do not run hot or make intrusive beeps. The small keyboard is part of the all-in-one unit, located below the screen, making it easily accessible, with small, closely spaced keys suitable for thumb-typing.
Readability:&nbsp; E-ink technology was developed at the MIT Media Lab in about 2004. A little like an Etch-A-Sketch, it forms letters by rearranging chemicals under the surface of the screen, appearing much more like a printed page than pixilated font on a computer screen. The Kindle also allows the user to change the font size.
